name: Pericles
characters: GOWER, fourteenth-century poet and Chorus of the play
THAISA, princess of Pentapolis and wife to Pericles
MARINA, daughter of Pericles and Thaisa
Five KNIGHTS, suitors for the hand of Thaisa
LYCHORIDA, attendant to Thaisa and, later, to Marina
Two SAILORS, mariners onboard ship from Pentapolis
LORD CERIMON, a wiseman/physician in Ephesus
BAWD, mistress of brothel and wife to Pander
BOLT, servant to Pander and Bawd
summary:
The nautical tale of a wandering prince, Pericles is narrated by John
Gower, a poet from the English past. Gower explains that Pericles,
Prince of Tyre, hopes to win the hand of a princess in Antioch. When
Pericles learns that she and the king, her father, are lovers, he flees for
his life.
Pericles brings grain to Tarsus during a famine, but loses his ships and
men in a storm. In Pentapolis, Pericles wins a tournament and marries
the king’s daughter, Thaisa. With Thaisa pregnant, she and Pericles
sail for Tyre. Thaisa bears a daughter, Marina, at sea, but apparently
dies. Her coffin drifts ashore at Ephesus, where she is revived and
becomes a priestess of Diana.
Pericles leaves the baby Marina with the king and queen of Tarsus.
Fourteen years later, Marina, kidnapped by pirates, is sold to a
brothel, but her eloquence protects her. Told that she has died, a griefstricken
Pericles rediscovers her. Guided by a vision from the goddess
Diana, Pericles and Marina reunite with Thaisa.
